trans-unit.source: Managing Role-Based Access Control with Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Managing Role-Based Access Control with Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Managing role-based access control with Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Managing role-based access control with Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Role-Based access control (RBAC) in the Azure Portal and Azure Resource Management API allows you to manage access to your subscription at a fine-grained level.
trans-unit.target: Role-Based access control (RBAC) in the Azure Portal and Azure Resource Management API allows you to manage access to your subscription at a fine-grained level.

trans-unit.source: With this feature, you can grant access for Active Directory users, groups, or service principals by assigning some roles to them at a particular scope.
trans-unit.target: With this feature, you can grant access for Active Directory users, groups, or service principals by assigning some roles to them at a particular scope.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to use Windows PowerShell to manage RBAC.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to use Windows PowerShell to manage RBAC.

trans-unit.source: It walks you through the process of creating and checking role assignments.
trans-unit.target: It walks you through the process of creating and checking role assignments.

trans-unit.source: Estimated time to complete: 15 minutes
trans-unit.target: Estimated time to complete: 15 minutes

trans-unit.source: Before you can use Windows PowerShell to manage RBAC, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you can use Windows PowerShell to manage RBAC, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell, Version 3.0 or 4.0.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell, Version 3.0 or 4.0.

trans-unit.source: To find the version of Windows PowerShell, type:$PSVersionTable and verify that the value of PSVersion is 3.0 or 4.0.
trans-unit.target: To find the version of Windows PowerShell, type:$PSVersionTable and verify that the value of PSVersion is 3.0 or 4.0.

trans-unit.source: To install a compatible version, see <linkText>Windows Management Framework 3.0 </linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Windows Management Framework 4.0</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To install a compatible version, see <linkText>Windows Management Framework 3.0 </linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Windows Management Framework 4.0</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell version 0.8.8 or later.
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell version 0.8.8 or later.

trans-unit.source: To install the latest version and associate it with your Azure subscription, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To install the latest version and associate it with your Azure subscription, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is designed for Windows PowerShell beginners, but it assumes that you understand the basic concepts, such as modules, cmdlets, and sessions.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is designed for Windows PowerShell beginners, but it assumes that you understand the basic concepts, such as modules, cmdlets, and sessions.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Windows PowerShell, see <linkText>Getting Started with Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Windows PowerShell, see <linkText>Getting Started with Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To get detailed help for any cmdlet that you see in this tutorial, use the Get-Help cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To get detailed help for any cmdlet that you see in this tutorial, use the Get-Help cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For example, to get help for the Add-AzureAccount cmdlet, type:
trans-unit.target: For example, to get help for the Add-AzureAccount cmdlet, type:

trans-unit.target: Please also read the following tutorials to get familiar with set up and using Azure Resource Manager in Windows PowerShell:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Using Windows PowerShell with Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Using Windows PowerShell with Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Since RBAC only works with Azure Resource Manager, the first thing to do is to switch to Azure Resource Manager mode, type:
trans-unit.target: Since RBAC only works with Azure Resource Manager, the first thing to do is to switch to Azure Resource Manager mode, type:

trans-unit.source: For more information, please refer to <linkText>Using Windows PowerShell with Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, please refer to <linkText>Using Windows PowerShell with Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To connect o your Azure subscriptions, type:
trans-unit.target: To connect o your Azure subscriptions, type:

trans-unit.source: In the pop-up browser control, enter you Azure account user name and password.
trans-unit.target: In the pop-up browser control, enter you Azure account user name and password.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell will get all the subscriptions you have with this account and figure PowerShell to use the first one as default.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell will get all the subscriptions you have with this account and figure PowerShell to use the first one as default.

trans-unit.source: Notice that with RBAC, you will only be able to get the subscriptions where you have some permissions by either being its co-admin or having some role assignment.
trans-unit.target: Notice that with RBAC, you will only be able to get the subscriptions where you have some permissions by either being its co-admin or having some role assignment.

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple subscriptions and want to switch to another one, type:
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple subscriptions and want to switch to another one, type:

trans-unit.source: For more information, please refer to <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, please refer to <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Now let's check what role assignments exist in the subscription already.
trans-unit.target: Now let's check what role assignments exist in the subscription already.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: This will return all the role assignments in the subscription.
trans-unit.target: This will return all the role assignments in the subscription.

trans-unit.source: Two things to notice:
trans-unit.target: Two things to notice:

trans-unit.source: You'll need to have read access at the subscription level.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to have read access at the subscription level.

trans-unit.source: If the subscription has a lot of role assignment, it may take a while to get all of them.
trans-unit.target: If the subscription has a lot of role assignment, it may take a while to get all of them.

trans-unit.source: You can also check existing role assignments for a particular role definition, at a particular scope to a particular user.
trans-unit.target: You can also check existing role assignments for a particular role definition, at a particular scope to a particular user.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: This will return all the role assignments for a particular user in your AD tenant, who has a role assignment of "Owner" for resource group "group1".
trans-unit.target: This will return all the role assignments for a particular user in your AD tenant, who has a role assignment of "Owner" for resource group "group1".

trans-unit.source: The role assignment can come from two places:
trans-unit.target: The role assignment can come from two places:

trans-unit.source: A role assignment of "Owner" to the user for the resource group.
trans-unit.target: A role assignment of "Owner" to the user for the resource group.

trans-unit.source: A role assignment of "Owner" to the user for the parent of the resource group (the subscription in this case) because if you have any permission at a certain level, you'll have the same permissions to all its children.
trans-unit.target: A role assignment of "Owner" to the user for the parent of the resource group (the subscription in this case) because if you have any permission at a certain level, you'll have the same permissions to all its children.

trans-unit.source: All the parameters of this cmdlet are optional.
trans-unit.target: All the parameters of this cmdlet are optional.

trans-unit.source: You can combine them to check role assignments with different filters.
trans-unit.target: You can combine them to check role assignments with different filters.

trans-unit.source: To create a role assignment, you need to think about:
trans-unit.target: To create a role assignment, you need to think about:

trans-unit.source: Who you want to assign the role to: you can use the following Azure active directory cmdlets to see what users, groups and service principals you have in your AD tenant.
trans-unit.target: Who you want to assign the role to: you can use the following Azure active directory cmdlets to see what users, groups and service principals you have in your AD tenant.

trans-unit.source: What role you want to assign: you can use the following cmdlet to see the supported role definitions.
trans-unit.target: What role you want to assign: you can use the following cmdlet to see the supported role definitions.

trans-unit.source: What scope you want to assign: you have three levels for scopes
trans-unit.target: What scope you want to assign: you have three levels for scopes

trans-unit.source: Then use New-AzureRoleAssignment to create a role assignment.
trans-unit.target: Then use New-AzureRoleAssignment to create a role assignment.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: This will create a role assignment at the current subscription level for a user as a reader.
trans-unit.target: This will create a role assignment at the current subscription level for a user as a reader.

trans-unit.source: This will create a role assignment at a resource group level.
trans-unit.target: This will create a role assignment at a resource group level.

trans-unit.source: This will create a role assignment for a group at a resource group level.
trans-unit.target: This will create a role assignment for a group at a resource group level.

trans-unit.source: This will create a role assignment at a resource level.
trans-unit.target: This will create a role assignment at a resource level.

trans-unit.source: After you check that your account has some role assignments, you can actually see the permissions these role assignments grant you by running
trans-unit.target: After you check that your account has some role assignments, you can actually see the permissions these role assignments grant you by running

trans-unit.source: These two cmdlets will only return the resource groups or resources where you have read permission.
trans-unit.target: These two cmdlets will only return the resource groups or resources where you have read permission.

trans-unit.source: And it will show you the permissions you have as well.
trans-unit.target: And it will show you the permissions you have as well.

trans-unit.source: Then when you try to run other cmdlet like New-AzureResourceGroup, you will get an access denied error if you don't have the permission.
trans-unit.target: Then when you try to run other cmdlet like New-AzureResourceGroup, you will get an access denied error if you don't have the permission.
